abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Ceara Second Sector Wide
            Approach (SWAP) Inclusive Growth Project for Brazil were as
            follows: overall outcome was satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, and both the Bank
            and the Borrower performance were satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: (1) Coordination is a challenge. The
            project's success owed much to the strong role played
            by Ceara Economic Research Institute (IPECE) in conducting
            monthly project meetings and following up as problems arose.
            Nevertheless, fifteen partners pushed the limits of what
            could be managed effectively. (2) Beware the use of outcome
            indicators that may readily escape government control. (3)
            Secondary indicators proved to be a useful innovation of the
            project to retain a focus on an important outcome metric
            when attribution fidelity was lacking. (4) Coordination
            between distinct levels of government can be particularly
            fraught. This problem underscores the importance of
            restricting indicators, so far as possible, to
            actions/activities substantially controlled by the client.
            (5) Extraordinary efforts are warranted during project
            design to reduce information asymmetries. (6) How much
            flexibility is too much? Some flexibility is warranted for
            the World Bank to approve modifications or extensions to
            meet performance targets. However, a high degree of
            flexibility risks undermining the performance incentives of
            the targets. The Bank should consider stipulating in the
            project documentation that major accommodations must be
            justified by factors fully beyond Government of Ceara control.
